items.body:
Something landed recently related to eslint and broke our CI.

https://ci.nodejs.org/job/node-test-commit-linux-containered/29888/#showFailuresLink

I guess it might be the most recent eslint update https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/41085. Seems like we do not require a CI run to land updates in `tools`? We might want to reconsider that.

items.title: Custom `completed` event is not triggered due to missing `data` event.
Stability Request: ESM Loader experimental status is holding EVERYTHING back

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

labels.name: loaders
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to ES module loaders

items.body:
Hey Node team, 
I'm creating this issue to point out something that I'm not sure is obvious to everyone, but the [lack of (stated) stability](https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#loaders) in the ESM loader API is holding the *entire* JavaScript ecosystem from adopting ESM in node. 

What's happening is indirect. Unit testing libs absolutely [need this functionality](https://jestjs.io/docs/ecmascript-modules) for mocking. Since they can't go forward, no one else in with a legit JS app can move forward. 

These loaders have remained in experimental status for many years, not sure what can be done to get them stable faster.

items.title: Unsupported character(s) in import module-name

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

items.body:
### Version

16.13.0

### Platform

Microsoft Windows NT 10.0.19043.0 x64

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

- create a file to run the code, e.g. `server.js`:
```javascript
import { userZero } from './#user/user0.js'
console.log(userZero)
```
- create `package.json`:
```javascript
{
    "type": "module"
}
```
- create a folder starting with `#` (probably not the only unsupported character), e.g. `#user`
- create a file in this folder, e.g. `user0.js`:
```javascript
export const userZero = 'This is a user.'
```

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Node.js always throws an unconditional error during the import.

### What is the expected behavior?

It should log the string.

### What do you see instead?

```javascript
PS D:\issue> node .\server.js
node:internal/process/esm_loader:94
    internalBinding('errors').triggerUncaughtException(
                              ^

Error [ERR_UNSUPPORTED_DIR_IMPORT]: Directory import 'D:\issue\' is not supported resolving ES modules imported from D:\issue\server.js
Did you mean to import ../#user/user0.js?
    at new NodeError (node:internal/errors:371:5)
    at finalizeResolution (node:internal/modules/esm/resolve:412:17)
    at moduleResolve (node:internal/modules/esm/resolve:932:10)
    at defaultResolve (node:internal/modules/esm/resolve:1044:11)
    at ESMLoader.resolve (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:422:30)
    at ESMLoader.getModuleJob (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:222:40)
    at ModuleWrap.<anonymous> (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:76:40)
    at link (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:75:36) {
  code: 'ERR_UNSUPPORTED_DIR_IMPORT',
  url: 'file:///D:/issue/#user/user0.js'
}
```

### Additional information

- `npm -v`: 8.1.0
- It does not matter whether a relative or absolute path is used, although the error is slightly different
- Trying to escape `\` the `#` does not work
- If you remove the `#`, it works as expected
- Node.js seems to think I want to import a directory before the `#`, yet is aware of the rest of the full path...?
- The suggested solution ("Did you mean to import ...") is complete nonsense in this case
- I couldn't find a list if unsupported characters for `import module-names`, so I have to assume there is none, which would mean that every character should be supported, especially since it's just a string pointing to a file
- Thought I was going crazy when this simple import refused to work, so I made sure everything else works fine multiple times...

Edit: Typo

items.body:
### Version

present in LTS through 17.10

### Platform

any

### Subsystem

any

### What steps will reproduce the bug?
```
> var number = 123
undefined
> number.toLocaleString("en-GB", {style: "currency", currency: "MYR" })
'MYRÂ 123.00'
```

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

always

### What is the expected behavior?
```
> var number = 123
 undefined
> number.toLocaleString("en-GB", {style: "currency", currency: "MYR" })
 'RMÂ 123.00'
```

### What do you see instead?
```
> var number = 123
undefined
> number.toLocaleString("en-GB", {style: "currency", currency: "MYR" })
'MYRÂ 123.00'
```

### Additional information

MYR is the Malaysian Ringgit. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysian_ringgit

We have missed updating the docs.

> This property is guaranteed to be an instance of the <net.Socket> class, a subclass of <stream.Duplex>, unless the user specified a socket type other than <net.Socket>.

items.title: filehandle.read doesn't conform to docs
items.body:
### Version

v17.1.0

### Platform

Darwin jim-book 19.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 19.6.0: Tue Oct 12 18:34:05 PDT 2021; root:xnu-6153.141.43~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64

### Subsystem

fs/promises

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

const fsp = require('node:fs/promises');
const f = await fsp.open('node/LICENSE', 'r');
const mybuf = new Uint8Array(1024);
const result = await f.read(mybuf.buffer, mybuf.byteOffset, mybuf.byteLength, 0);
console.log(result.bytesRead<=1024, result.buffer===mybuf, result.buffer.buffer===mybuf.buffer);


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior?

From [the documentation of filehandle.read](https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v17.x/docs/api/fs.html#filehandlereadbuffer-offset-length-position), I'd expect the log output to be `true, true, true`.

### What do you see instead?

`false. false, false`

### Additional information

_No response_

items.title: Allow for importing .geojson files as JSON

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues that look for answers.

labels.name: experimental
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to experimental features.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

labels.name: loaders
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to ES module loaders

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I currently use the [experimental JSON module loader](https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#json-modules) in ESM mode. I would to import JSON files that have a `.geojson` extension. I know that I can just name the files with a `.json` extension (so far as I know GeoJSON is completely valid JSON)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Seems like it could be a small thing to allow importing JSON files with a `.geojson` extension (which is why I'm trying my luck by submitting an issue)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Naming my GeoJSON files with a `.json` extension. This is fine, but it's nice to be able to see which JSON files are GeoJSON just from the file extension.

items.body:
### Version

v16.13.0

### Platform

Darwin xxx.local 20.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 20.6.0: Tue Oct 12 18:33:38 PDT 2021; root:xnu-7195.141.8~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8101 arm64

### Subsystem

net

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

> net.isIP("192.0250.1.1")
0
> net.isIP("030052000401")
0
> net.isIP("0xc0.168.1.1")
0
> net.isIP("3232235777")
0
> net.isIP("127.42.258")
0
> net.isIP("127.66051")
0
> net.isIP("10.1.1.0xff")

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior?

4

### What do you see instead?

0

### Additional information

I was looking for a way of checking if a hostname in an URL is an IP (v4 or V6) and found the "net" nodejs module. But it is unable to detect different formats. Open a browser and put any of the strings in the description, with a http:// in front, and see  that it is correctly converted to the canonical form.
Also would be great if you could add the conversion to canonical form for both ipv4 and ipv6 (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5952#section-4)

items.title: Adopt Semantic Versioning 2.0.0: returning `X.Y.Z` instead of `vX.Y.Z` for `node -v`

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Following https://github.com/nodejs/node/discussions/40957, Node.js version format contains a `v`-prefix prior the version, e.g. `node -v` returns `v17.1.0`. According to the https://semver.org/#is-v123-a-semantic-version, `v17.1.0` is not semver compliant.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Drop `v` from the version number and return `17.1.0` for `node -v`.

It should not be a problem at all if implemented in a [major version](https://semver.org/#summary):

> _MAJOR version when you make incompatible API changes_

Besides, if a Node.js version check implemented properly, not just substringing the first char, it should not break anything.

items.title: Nominating Tierney Cyren (bnb) to be a collaborator

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

items.body:
<!--
Thank you for suggesting an idea to make Node.js better.

Please fill in as much of the template below as you're able.
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Lack of bnb in collaborator team.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

bnb in collaborator team.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

bnb in triage team.

--

I'd like to nominate Tierney Cyren (@bnb) to be a collaborator. While their code contributions to core are small thus far, their involvement in the project specifically and the community in general is significant and therefore (IMO) warrants a nomination.

Tierney is a member of the Moderation Team and was the chair of the Community Committee for (I think) the last few years. They have been involved in many `nodejs` org repositories (see first link in bulleted list that follows).

* Pull requests and issues opened throughout the Node.js organization: https://github.com/search?q=author:bnb+org:nodejs
* Commits in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/commits?author=bnb
* Pull requests and issues in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues?q=author:bnb
* Comments on pull requests and issues in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues?q=commenter:bnb
* Reviews on pull requests in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pulls?q=reviewed-by:bnb
* Help provided to end-users and novice contributors: https://github.com/nodejs/help/issues?q=commenter:bnb

items.title: Delete this please.
items.body:
Argh. I forgot to export.
Gotta love JS and its `undefined`.
This is a non-issue.
Delete this please.

**EDIT**: OK. So this is indeed a bug where I found it in `v12.22.6`, but in simplifying it for the bug report I omitted the `module.exports` and so I believed to have found it in the newer node version, where it no longer exists.

items.title: `Nan::NewBuffer` doesn't free the passed buffer until the final cleanup if the code is synchronous
items.body:
### Version

16.10

### Platform

All

### Subsystem

Buffer

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

This simple example does it: <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65797684/node-add-on-nannewbuffer-causes-memory-leak>

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior?

Buffers with external backing store should have their external storage deallocated when they are GCed

### What do you see instead?

The deallocation happens in a `SetImmediate` handler and it is never triggered in tight synchronous loops

items.title: stream.PassThrough not draining (from Node 16)

labels.name: stream
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the stream subsystem.

items.body:
### Version

v16.13.0

### Platform

Linux david-Latitude-E6440 5.13.0-21-generic #21-Ubuntu SMP Tue Oct 19 08:59:28 UTC 2021 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Subsystem

stream

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

```js
const { PassThrough } = require('stream');
const pt = new PassThrough({ highWaterMark: 0 });
pt.on('drain', () => console.log('drained'));
console.log(pt.write('hello'));
console.log(pt.writableLength, pt.writableNeedDrain);
console.log(pt.read().toString());
console.log(pt.writableLength, pt.writableNeedDrain);
```


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Every time

### What is the expected behavior?

On Node 14:

```bash
david@david-Latitude-E6440:/tmp$ node --version
v14.18.1
david@david-Latitude-E6440:/tmp$ node repro.js 
false
5 true
drained
hello
0 false
```

### What do you see instead?

On Node 16:

```bash
david@david-Latitude-E6440:/tmp$ node --version
v16.13.0
david@david-Latitude-E6440:/tmp$ node repro.js 
false
5 true
hello
5 true
```

### Additional information

_No response_

items.title: const array is changing its value when assigned to a temp variable in loop.
items.body:
### Version

v16.13.0

### Platform

Linux floof-ms7b86 5.15.2-2-MANJARO #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Nov 13 19:25:38 UTC 2021 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Run this code

```
const test = ["",""]

let hold;
let x = 0;

while(x < 10){
    hold = test;
    hold[0] = "@"
    console.log({hold: hold, test: test})
    console.log(hold === test);
    x++;
}
```

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Only when trying to do what I am doing in the above code.

### What is the expected behavior?

Should not change test since test is a constant and not being directly assigned the value.
test is supposed to remain like this: `["",""]`

### What do you see instead?

`{ hold: [ '@', '' ], test: [ '@', '' ] }`

### Additional information

_No response_

items.title: Windows build of Node.js is using a static C runtime which leads to having separate heaps for its addons
items.body:
### Version

v16.10.0

### Platform

Windows

### Subsystem

node-gyp

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Use the default Windows build settings in `node-gyp` for Node addon - one will obtain a so-called "/MT" or "/MTd" build in Windows lingo

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

Always

### What is the expected behavior?

Ideally, Node.js should share a heap with its addons - an "/MD" or "/MDd" build in Windows lingo - but the reality is that this is not so simple on Windows - and changing the link settings would break all existing addons that come as prebuilt binaries

### What do you see instead?

Node addons have a separate heap on Windows
* Debug builds fail with an assert in `debug_heap.cpp:996`
* Release builds silently leak memory - the `free` doesn't work

### Additional information

Normally having separate heaps is not a showstopper - in fact, Microsoft recommends that all DLLs have their own separate memory management and that objects allocated in one DLL are always freed in the same DLL.
With the current API, `Nan::NewBuffer` and some callback pointers are notable exceptions.

See also:

https://github.com/nodejs/node-gyp/issues/1686
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/240332/assert-when-using-mtd-dynamic-library.html

items.title: C++ embedded V8 Crashes in snapshot serialization under LINUX 64-bit
items.body:
### Version

16.13.0

### Platform

Linux bld64rh8v01 4.18.0-305.10.2.el8_4.x86_64 #1 SMP Mon Jul 12 04:43:18 EDT 2021 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Subsystem

v8

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

This fails consistently while embedded in our C++ application. We have created a standalone C++ program to demonstrate the issue. It does not fail unless it is run with Valgrind where it will fail consistently. Am attaching the Valgrind output, the sample program, compile options and the snapshot binary file.

Valgrind shows a number of invalid memory accesses, the last of which causes the crash. However, the others are concerning to us as well.

[LinuxV8Crash.zip](https://github.com/nodejs/node/files/7582848/LinuxV8Crash.zip)



### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

When the code is embedded in our application it will crash everytime.

The interesting things is that the crash occurs on the second context creation although a number of memory errors are already occurring when the first context is created.


### What is the expected behavior?

Don't expect it to crash.

### What do you see instead?

SIGSEGV failure

### Additional information

_No response_
